„Cat Goes Fishing“ is surprisingly fun, especially with the simple game-mechanics and the relaxing music it has.You start the game as a simple cat, that – of course – goes fishing. Because every cat likes fish, right? In „Cat Goes Fishing“ you have to level up to achieve different things. You will get a shop quite early in the game to make it possible and upgrade your rods. By time, you will also be able to purchase things such as rockets or bombs to apply on your fishing rod. Later in the game you will be buying a boat to move into the depths of the ocean, getting even more rare fish than you got at the shore. The more money you make, the better upgrades and items you can buy. And during this process, you will level up and unlock several new things that will improve your gameplay. The game has 52 achievements to collect, most of them seem easy to achieve since they are bound to the quests you get in the game (hunting several fish, buying a special item), but a lot are also harder to get. Also, you will find two modes to play on. First one is normal, where you simply catch fish, sell them, level up. In realism mode, the fish will try to withstand when getting pulled out of the water. They won't make it far, most of them will get eaten by bigger fishes in the underground, so you will receive less money once you try to sell your prey.Overall, this game is nice to spend some time on, either when installing something else or just chilling out. It can possibly get addictive, especially when you like cats and fishing (?), but in the end it's just a short little game with more achievements than spectacular gameplay.

Cat Goes Fishing is a casual, cat-induced, 2-D fishing ‘simulator.’ The goal here is to use an array of tools, including rods, boats, even bombs in conjunction with upgrades to complete a host of quests.The casting mechanics are fairly straightforward, as there are only three buttons you’re likely to ever use. Click for casting/reeling & A/D for movement. There is no tutorial as of the writing of this review, but getting the general sense on how to start casting to maximum effect is quite simple. There isn’t any Menu either. While, the casting & movement mechanics couldn’t get any simpler, there is some depth on how you choose to complete the quests. There are many different types of effects you can apply to your rod to target or dissuade various types of fish or to augment other elements. There are also tools both temporary & permanent that will come in handy.As you catch fish & complete quests, you will level & accrue currency. As you level, the quests get progressively more difficult. However, from my experience, there does appear to be a degree of randomness with respect to the quest system; old quests will pop up time & again. The quests will progressively get more & more grindy. Completing them will require you to farm currency for pro-longed periods of time, before you can purchase the necessary items & upgrades to complete them.Hats! Hats! & More Hats! Yes, Cat Goes Fishing does have an array of hats. They are obtained by catching them so keep an eye out. The sad part is that you can’t collect them. You can only wear one hat at a time. Each hat provides a useful boost. Be wary of accidentally selling a hat, as it is easy to do. There is an in-game catalog giving various details on the different types of fish, so it may yield some assistance in catching your desired fish.The artwork is exactly as shown in the screenshots. The background scenery is under-utilized & quite bland. The sound is one uninspiring track looped continuously. Luckily, it can be muted with the ‘M’ key.In conclusion, I wouldn’t label Cat Goes Fishing as a fishing simulator. I wouldn’t recommend it to those who love fishing & desire that experience, albeit through the eyes of a cat. Rather, Cat Goes Fishing is a game you pop in when you have a few minutes to kill, just for the posterity of seeing a cat catch some fish, while wearing a snazzy hat.

												All jokes aside I would rate this game a solid 9.8/10. This game is fantastically zen and is great for stress relief. You can play it for 5 minutes or 2 hours. I have found myself immersed in 2-3 hour sessions of this wonderful indie title. Pros: - The art style is a perfect blend of cartoon and realism.- The quests, although some can be extremely difficult, present a nice balance of challenge, objective, and progression.- The developers are quick to patch bugs or errors and pay close attention to what the community has to offer. For examle, I posted a screenshot to show my friends that I had snagged my first legendary hat. I expressed that I felt that hat was slightly nerf. Within a week a developer had commented saying that next patch they would buff it. - The AI for the fish is so well build. Each one of the 40+ fish in the game have a unique fighting style when hooked. Also, some fish travel together, chase eachother, and some will protect their "leader." I would like to write more about the AI but it would take hours.- The game progression is layed out perfectly, the larger, and harder to catch fish are father out at sea which requres the player to buy a boat, stronger fish are deeper, which requres the player to buy a better rod. The prices are layed out perfectly so when you dont get all the rods, then all the boats, air vice versa. Cons: - The music can get a little repetitive, but this can easily be fixed. EDIT 1: Hat for new music was added :DTo be honest there arent that many cons :) Suggestions - I feel this game could improve visually by adding in more customization options. These could include rod colors, boat, colors, boat names.- Lastly, on realism mode I think a day night cycle could be cool. EDIT 1: Added For 6.99 this game is 100% worth it!

												This anime has some of the strongest character development I have ever seen,  the dub is seccond to girls und panzer, and it is probably my favorite anime besides king of the hill.Cat Goes Fishing is about the struggle of one cat and his quest to catch fish. As we start out the cat is just a simple prolitarean in a capitalist society. He sees the error of his society's ways and wants to rise up with his fellow workers against the oppressive corperate regeme he is living in. His father, who faithfully served for Whiskerslovakia as a boat millitarycat (also known as the navie) in the war against the hunter dogs, but was executed in the great fishpression of '92. After years of resenting his father, cat finally learned why his father was executed: "he was a scapegoat for it all" his revolutionary friend meowthew told him, and both of them should form a revolution against Whiskerslovakia.At a rally that cat and meowthew organized, police turned on the demonstrators and stated executing people in the streets. Meowthew died in cat's arms and cat found himself alive, not as an act of mercy, but to bear the suffering of his now dead best friend. Cat went back to his normal life and did not engage in any revolutionary activity until as the sole survivor of the riots he was approached by Mr. Meowgi, an old friend of his father. This is the last connection he had with his family, as his mom had died after childbirth. Mr. Meowgi gives cat a fishing rod, and cat was finally ready to accept his quest.Cat now knows he has has to leave. Our hero moves to the underground of the capital, Meowscow, and joins the underground resistance, leaving behind his girlfriend of five years, Sameowa. They were good together at first, but they had recently been going through trouble, and both were too busy to break things off. In the capital, his first assignment was to sabotauge regime fishing boats. Although a dangerous task, cat and his father before him were white cats, so they could easily blend in with the snow of Meowscow in Whiskerslovakia. Lapurrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrsha, a black cat, was also assigned to the mission, but she never made it to the boat. Instead, Lapurrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrsha was brutally beaten and captured. We can't be sure if she was captured for being a meowmber of the rebellion, or just for being black in an all white and calico society. This was the second time Cat saw the true face of his enemy. He successfully infultrated and sabotauged the boat, and soon forgot (three days max) Lapurrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrsha. After all, it's a cat kill cat world. Cat returns and recieves his sweet payment of catnip, and spends it on new armor for himself and an upgraded version of his fishing rod.Cat had overcame his trials and was now ready to fully face his enemy. He leads a ride into the city to assassinate a senetor, Wood. Cat had found out that Senetor Wood was the one who captured Lapurrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrsha, and had eventually killed her. Cat was ready for his vengance. Cat had now reached the senetor, and was prepared for an epic fight. All of his platoon was killed except for him, who completed his mission, and returned with newfound condidence that he could now face his true enemy, the ultamate evil, President Raftdog, who is actually a cat and not my English professer. With his mind set and his heart pure, he entered the Impurrial Meowice. Cat was surprised about how little people were on guard at the meowice. It was empty. Raftdog was alone and it was time to strike and take vengence for all that him and his evil regime had done to cat. Raftdog told cat, "I know my time has come, but the Whiskerslovakian Empire will rise again!" With these last words, cat swung a swift stroak with his trusty rusty fishing rod, and ended Raftdog's life, or so it seems.In the Meowice, cat finds Lapurrrrrrrrsha's lost collar, which was the key to her invunerability, and the whole reason why Lapurrrrrrrrrrrrrrrsha thought she could take the mission in the first place, unfortunately, the empire had found a way to bypass this invunerability, and captured Lapurrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrsha. When cat returned, he was celebrated by all, and bestowed the highest honor by Mr. Meowgi.In conclusion, I greatly enjoyed this anime, and can't wait for the second season to come out. This anime alone helped me achieve my doctoral degree, and was the topic of my thesis paper. I rate this anime 9.5/10 and hope that all of you reading this can experiene the greatness as I have.

												I think the title adequately explains what the game is about.This is the kind of game you play while you're waiting to do something else. The art is friendly and colorful. There's 1 music track (turn it off by pressing M) that you can hear in the trailer. The actual game is simple and fun. When you cast your line, you control where the bait moves. Then when you hook a fish, you have to reel it back while avoiding the other fish that may want to eat it. You'll have to use a different type of strategy to catch each fish.There's a leveling system where you can buy and upgrade things with the money from the fish you catch. It's a bit clunky and annoying to use, but I didn't feel that it took away from the game at all. You can buy different fishing rods and add some tweaks to augment your playing style. It's mostly to give you some goals and rewards.It's an okay game.  It's missing a few things, but what's there is fun to play with. If you're interested, I don't think you'll regret spending your five dollars.

												As you might have guessed, this game is about fishing !You are a cat, and your goal is to catch as many fish as possible. 												A simple, but entertaining time killer. Cat Goes Fishing is a fishing simulator from Cat5Games. Let’s get rocking.The GoodCat Goes Fishing gets everything just about perfect. The controls are as simple as they come and you won’t even need a tutorial to figure them out. If you did, you’d probably be some sort of mollusk…and not one of the smart ones.There is a delightful plethora of fish for you to catch. The small fries can be caught without any special baiting, but, the further up the scale you move, the bigger the bait you’re going to need to attract your Moby♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s interest.There are several items for you to purchase that will aid you in your fishing endeavors. You can get new rods (and upgrades for each of them), you can buy boats to take you out further onto the lake, you can get a sonar to show you where fish are in the lake, and much more.The boats were especially useful. Some fish only appear further out in the lake and, so, would be unreachable without a boat of some kind. The boat also lets you store a finite amount of fish so that you can sell them when you get back to shore.CGF offers the player “quests” to complete. This results in the player gaining experience and working towards a level up to unlock more gear, but it also fights back at the repetitiveness of the game itself. When you’re given a goal to work towards, you don’t get bored quite as much.The BadInevitably, CGF does become repetitive. There’s only so much digital fishing one can do before they get tired of it.The MehCGF also has hats for you to find in the depths and equip your character with. The hats are absurdly hard to find and you rarely come across one at a moment when you could actually try and snag it with your hook.Verdict: YeaCat Goes Fishing is fun, but it’s more of a novelty game for killing time. If you see it go on sale, by all means, buy it. It’s worth of few bucks. You can find it in the Steam Store. As always, thanks for reading.

												Pretty simple, casual 2D fishing simulator. Visuals are nice, animations are fine, and music is okay to listen to for a while (then press M to turn it off). Upgrades come in pretty quickly at first, then mid-game there is a lot of unrewarded gold grind while you save for better rods + upgrades, boats, and other upgrades. Quests are decent gold but you can easily get stuck on a quest if you haven't gotten the proper rod/upgrades yet. Also, fish take time to respawn so you may have to wait for the fish you want (or get a boat to increase your fishing range). At end-game once you can grind the shark/maw/anglerfish, gold comes in quickly enough to upgrade everything you want and more.Fishing is pretty straightforward: catch a small fish to catch a medium fish to catch a large/huge fish while avoiding fish you don't want to catch. I upgraded reel speed and lure sink speed to better avoid fish I didn't want to take. The Bait Guard and Crankbait upgrades are really useful, but are also very expensive to grind. Minimap and radar upgrades are nice for avoiding unwanted fish, though you can throw your line beyond the radar (which might be fixed in the beta). Radar is also useful for finding where the Maw/Anglerfish spawn and where you can cast to avoid the most fish on the way down.Pretty fun for a 2D fishing simulator, though I would've liked more special fish like the shark. The shark takes your live fish and drags your line further away, effectively extending your rod's reach further than you normally could go. It's pretty fun to use when you're starting out with mediocre rods and no boat, but I don't think there's any more sharks further out so everything beyond the initial screen is just simple fishing.
